elements.content: Four bent ligands, (i) 4,4′-abpt, (ii) 4,4′-Hbpt, (iii) 3,4′-Hbpt, and (iv) 3,3′-Hbpt, as well as H2suc (succinic acid) have been utilized to construct seven coordination polymers: [Co(suc)(4,4′-abpt)(H2O)2]·H2O (1), [M(suc)(4,4′-Hbpt)(H2O)]·2H2O (M = Co for 2, Ni for 3), [Cd(suc)(4,4′-Hbpt)2(H2O)2] (4), [Co(suc)(3,4′-Hbpt)(H2O)3]·H2O (5), [Zn(suc)(3,4′-Hbpt)] (6), and [Zn(suc)0.5(3,3′-bpt)(H2O)] (7) (4,4′-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 4,4′-Hbpt = 1H-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 3,4'-Hbpt = 1H-3-(3-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, and 3,3′-Hbpt = 1H-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole). The crystal structure analysis reveals that 1–3 form similar two-dimensional (2D) layer structures, where the adjacent metal centers are connected by a syn–anti carboxylate bridge from suc ligands to furnish a succinate-metal chain, which is further interlinked by bent ligands. 4–7 form different 1D chains via suc anions, and bpt isomers display versatile coordination modes. The magnetic behavior of compounds 1–3 and 5 was studied, and it indicated the existence of interesting spin-canting behavior, where the bent ligands tilting the neighbor metal center could give further contribution to the canting effect. In addition, the luminescent properties of 4, 6, and 7 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: The design and construction of coordination polymers has attracted more attention not only because of their fascinating network topologies and structural diversities but also because of the potential applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, magnetism, photoluminescence, and medicine. The design and preparation, as well as the structure–property relationships, are very important topics and also great challenges in this field. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of coordination polymers has attracted more attention not only because of their fascinating network topologies and structural diversities but also because of the potential applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, magnetism, photoluminescence, and medicine. The design and preparation, as well as the structure-property relationships, are very important topics and also great challenges in this field. The structural natures are diverse depending on the metal ions, pH, solvents, the ligands and/or coligands, synthetic methods, etc. To date, reasonable design of ligands continues to be an attractive and difficult goal.

elements.content: In recent decades, indeed, the linear 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) and 4,4′-bipyridine-like N,N′-donor building blocks, which have shown the capability of yielding various coordination compounds, have been extensive used as building blocks to extend coordination polymers. A little attention has been paid to the bent ligands, which introduce moieties between the two pyridyl groups. That is so far what has been paid close attention to in our research group. We focus here on the bent ligands which introduce 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole and 1H-1,2,4-triazole moieties between the two pyridyl groups and change the position of the pyridyl N atoms. The different degrees of bending which are caused by the changing position of the pyridyl N atoms could benefit the formation of different topological structures and, moreover, may give an antisymmetric interaction between the spin carries. In addition, introducing the simple aliphatic dicarboxylate as the coligand can result in adoption of different bridging modes (including syn–syn, anti–anti, and syn–anti) to bridging two or more metal ions into various coordination compounds.

A little attention has been paid to the bent ligands, which introduce moieties between the two pyridyl groups. That is so far what has been paid close attention to in our research group. We focus here on the bent ligands which introduce 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole and 1H-1,2,4-triazole moieties between the two pyridyl groups and change the position of the pyridyl N atoms. The different degrees of bending which are caused by the changing position of the pyridyl N atoms could benefit the formation of different topological structures and, moreover, may give an antisymmetric interaction between the spin carries. In addition, introducing the simple aliphatic dicarboxylate as the coligand can result in adoption of different bridging modes (including syn-syn, anti-anti, and syn-anti) to bridging two or more metal ions into various coordination compounds.

elements.content: Currently, in view of the reported work on the constructions of coordination polymers and our previous research, we choose the above-mentioned bispyridyl-1,2,4-triazole building blocks [4,4′-abpt, 4,4′-Hbpt, 3,4′-Hbpt, 3,3′-Hbpt (4,4′-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole), 4,4′-Hbpt = 1H-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 3,4'-Hbpt = 1H-3-(3-pyridyl-5,4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 3,3′-Hbpt = 1H-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (Chart )] and succinic acid to assemble new coordination frameworks with interesting properties. A series of coordination polymers, namely, [Co(suc)(4,4′-abpt)(H2O)2]·H2O (1), [M(suc)(4,4′-Hbpt)(H2O)]·2H2O (M = Co for 2, Ni for 3), [Cd(suc)(4,4′-Hbpt)2(H2O)2] (4), [Co(suc)(3,4′-Hbpt)(H2O)3]·H2O (5), [Zn(suc)(3,4′-Hbpt)] (6), and [Zn(suc)0.5(3,3′-bpt)(H2O)] (7), are constructed successfully by the hydrothermal technique. They provide new samples to evaluate the effects of structural diversity by the bent ligands. Meanwhile, an interesting spin-canting behavior has been found in 1–3 and 5, and the luminescent properties of 4, 6, and 7 also have been explored.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received except the bpt ligands, which were prepared according to the literature procedure. The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an model 2400 II, Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on polycrystalline samples using a Quantum Design MPMSXL7 SQUID magnetometer with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe over the temperature range of 2–300 K. Field dependences of magnetization generated with a conventional pulsed technique were measured using a flux magnetometer in an applied field up to 50 kOe. A diamagnetic correction to the observed susceptibilities was applied using Pascal’s constants. Steady state fluorescence measurements were performed using a FL3-P-TCSPC steady-state fluorescence spectrofluorometer at room temperature in the solid-state.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received except the bpt ligands, which were prepared according to the literature procedure. The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on an model 2400 II, Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained on polycrystalline samples using a Quantum Design MPMSXL7 SQUID magnetometer with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe over the temperature range of 2-300 K. Field dependences of magnetization generated with a conventional pulsed technique were measured using a flux magnetometer in an applied field up to 50 kOe. A diamagnetic correction to the observed susceptibilities was applied using Pascal's constants. Steady state fluorescence measurements were performed using a FL3-P-TCSPC steady-state fluorescence spectrofluorometer at room temperature in the solid-state.

elements.content: All reflection data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD instrument by using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. A semiempirical absorption correction by using the SADABS program was applied, and the raw data frame integration was performed with SAINT. The crystal structures were solved by the direct method using the program SHELXS-97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 for all non-hydrogen atoms using SHELXTL-97 with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in calculated positions and refined isotropically, except the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were fixed in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The details of the crystal data were summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1–7 are listed in Table S1 (). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers: 714842 (1), 837972–837977 (2–7).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Determination

All reflection data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD instrument by using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. A semiempirical absorption correction by using the SADABS program was applied, and the raw data frame integration was performed with SAINT. The crystal structures were solved by the direct method using the program SHELXS-97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 for all non-hydrogen atoms using SHELXTL-97 with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in calculated positions and refined isotropically, except the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were fixed in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The details of the crystal data were summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1-7 are listed in Table S1 (). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers: 714842 (1), 837972-837977 (2-7).

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments have also been carried out for 1–7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the , Figure S4–S10. Although the experimental patterns have few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single crystal models, it can still be considered favorable that the bulk synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous for 1–7.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments have also been carried out for 1-7. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the , Figure S4-S10. Although the experimental patterns have few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single crystal models, it can still be considered favorable that the bulk synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous for 1-7.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two independent Co(II) cations; both of them lie on inversion centers. As illustrated in Figure , Co1 is six-coordinated, showing an octahedral environment, which is provided by two pyridyl N donors (N1 and N1A) occupying the apical plane and four carboxylate O atoms (O1, O1A, O3, and O3A) composing the equatorial plane; the corresponding Co–N and Co–O distances are 2.164(2) and 2.051(1)–2.059(1) Å, respectively. Co2 displays a similar octahedral environment, which is bonded by two pyridyl N atoms (N6C and N6D) and four carboxylate/water O atoms (O4, O4B, O5, and O5B). The adjacent centers are bridged by syn–anti carboxylate bridges from suc ligands with a separation of 5.256(1) Å to furnish a polymeric chain. These 1-D arrays are further interlinked along the bc plane to generate a 2-D net through 4,4′-abpt ligands, with a Co···Co separation of 14.654(3) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of the Complexes

[Co(suc)(4,4'-abpt)(H2O)2]⋅H2O (1)

The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two independent Co(II) cations; both of them lie on inversion centers. As illustrated in Figure , Co1 is six-coordinated, showing an octahedral environment, which is provided by two pyridyl N donors (N1 and N1A) occupying the apical plane and four carboxylate O atoms (O1, O1A, O3, and O3A) composing the equatorial plane; the corresponding Co-N and Co-O distances are 2.164(2) and 2.051(1)-2.059(1) Å, respectively. Co2 displays a similar octahedral environment, which is bonded by two pyridyl N atoms (N6C and N6D) and four carboxylate/water O atoms (O4, O4B, O5, and O5B). The adjacent centers are bridged by syn-anti carboxylate bridges from suc ligands with a separation of 5.256(1) Å to furnish a polymeric chain. These 1-D arrays are further interlinked along the bc plane to generate a 2-D net through 4,4'-abpt ligands, with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 14.654(3) Å.

elements.content: Local coordination environments of the Co(II) atoms (left), the 1-D [Co(suc)] n chain (top right), and the 2-D layer of 1 formed by the [Co(suc)] n chain and 4,4′-abpt connector (bottom right).
elements.clean_text: 1  Local coordination environments of the Co(II) atoms (left), the 1-D [Co(suc)] n  chain (top right), and the 2-D layer of 1 formed by the [Co(suc)] n  chain and 4,4'-abpt connector (bottom right).

elements.content: Further studies of the crystallographic data have shown that the 2D layer is further packed into a 3D structure through intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions by creating an interesting six-membered ring (Figure a, Table S2 in the ), which are located around the inversion center formed by four unbound water molecules and the two unbound carboxylate O atoms. In addition, the hydrogen bonds among the 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole N atoms and unbound water molecules, and the two unbound carboxylate O allow the formation of a 1D hexagon tunnel along the b axis (Figure b).

In addition, the hydrogen bonds among the 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole N atoms and unbound water molecules, and the two unbound carboxylate O allow the formation of a 1D hexagon tunnel along the b axis (Figure b).

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural with an identical space group and similar cell dimensions; they have a similar 2-D polymeric coordination layer structure to that of 1 but a slight change in the structure dipyridyl ligand from 4,4′-abpt to 4,4′-Hbpt. As illustrated in Figure , both crystallographically independent M(II) ions show a similar octahedral environment, and the adjacent central M(II) atoms are connected by a syn–anti carboxylate bridge from suc ligands with a same separation of 5.342(1) Å to furnish a 1-D chain. The further interlink along the bc plane through 4,4′-Hbpt ligands generate a 2-D net, with a M···M separation of 14.494(3) Å. The 2-D net is also packed into a 3D structure through intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions creating a six-membered ring (Figure S1a and Table S2 in the ), the hydrogen bonds among the 1H-1,2,4-triazole N atoms, the unbound water molecules, and the two unbound carboxylate O, allowing the formation of a 1D hexagon tunnel along the b axis (Figure S1b in the ).

[M(suc)(4,4'-Hbpt)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (M = Co for 2, Ni for 3)

Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural with an identical space group and similar cell dimensions; they have a similar 2-D polymeric coordination layer structure to that of 1 but a slight change in the structure dipyridyl ligand from 4,4'-abpt to 4,4'-Hbpt. As illustrated in Figure , both crystallographically independent M(II) ions show a similar octahedral environment, and the adjacent central M(II) atoms are connected by a syn-anti carboxylate bridge from suc ligands with a same separation of 5.342(1) Å to furnish a 1-D chain. The further interlink along the bc plane through 4,4'-Hbpt ligands generate a 2-D net, with a M⋅⋅⋅M separation of 14.494(3) Å. The 2-D net is also packed into a 3D structure through intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions creating a six-membered ring (Figure S1a and Table S2 in the ), the hydrogen bonds among the 1H-1,2,4-triazole N atoms, the unbound water molecules, and the two unbound carboxylate O, allowing the formation of a 1D hexagon tunnel along the b axis (Figure S1b in the ).

elements.content: Compound 4 reveals a 1-D system with a mononuclear Cd(II) unit. The central cadmium atom Cd1 is located on a crystallographic inversion center with an octahedron coordination sphere (Figure ). Four carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O1A, O3, O3A, Cd–O = 2.272(2)–2.356(2) Å) composed the equatorial positions, and the two pyridyl N atoms (N1, N1A, Cd–N = 2.345(2) Å) occupied the axially positions. The adjacent central cadmium atoms are connected by suc ligands with a separation of 9.594(2) Å to furnish a 1-D chain. As illustrated in Figure , both of the carboxylic groups in the suc ligands adopt monodentate coordination fashions to bridge two Cd atoms, and the 4,4′-Hbpt ligands are in monodentate coordination modes also.

[Cd(suc)(4,4'-bpt)2(H2O)2] (4)

Compound 4 reveals a 1-D system with a mononuclear Cd(II) unit. The central cadmium atom Cd1 is located on a crystallographic inversion center with an octahedron coordination sphere (Figure ). Four carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O1A, O3, O3A, Cd-O = 2.272(2)-2.356(2) Å) composed the equatorial positions, and the two pyridyl N atoms (N1, N1A, Cd-N = 2.345(2) Å) occupied the axially positions. The adjacent central cadmium atoms are connected by suc ligands with a separation of 9.594(2) Å to furnish a 1-D chain. As illustrated in Figure , both of the carboxylic groups in the suc ligands adopt monodentate coordination fashions to bridge two Cd atoms, and the 4,4'-Hbpt ligands are in monodentate coordination modes also.

elements.content: Compound 5 belongs to the orthorhombic Pna21 space group and reveals a 1-D system with a mononuclear Co(II) unit. The central cobalt atom Co1 is located on a distorted octahedron coordination sphere (Figure ). The equatorial positions are composed by four carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O5, O6, O7, Co–O = 2.027(6)–2.144(6) Å), and the two pyridyl N atoms (N1, N5A, Co–N = 2.121(6)–2.138(6) Å) occupy the axially positions. As shown in Figure , the adjacent central cobalt atom is bridged by 3,4′-Hbpt ligands with a separation of 11.133(1) Å to furnish a 1-D chain, where the suc ligands only adopt monodentate coordination fashions. In addition, the three coordination water O atoms and 1H-1,2,4-triazole N atoms (O5, O6, O7, N4) as the H-donors link the uncoordinated carboxylate/water O and another 1H-1,2,4-triazole N (O2, O3, O4, O8, N3) of a neighboring molecule through hydrogen bonding interactions to furnish a 3D architecture (Figure S2 in the ).

The central cobalt atom Co1 is located on a distorted octahedron coordination sphere (Figure ). The equatorial positions are composed by four carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O5, O6, O7, Co-O = 2.027(6)-2.144(6) Å), and the two pyridyl N atoms (N1, N5A, Co-N = 2.121(6)-2.138(6) Å) occupy the axially positions. As shown in Figure , the adjacent central cobalt atom is bridged by 3,4'-Hbpt ligands with a separation of 11.133(1) Å to furnish a 1-D chain, where the suc ligands only adopt monodentate coordination fashions. In addition, the three coordination water O atoms and 1H-1,2,4-triazole N atoms (O5, O6, O7, N4) as the H-donors link the uncoordinated carboxylate/water O and another 1H-1,2,4-triazole N (O2, O3, O4, O8, N3) of a neighboring molecule through hydrogen bonding interactions to furnish a 3D architecture (Figure S2 in the ).

elements.content: Compound 6 reveals a 1-D system with a mononuclear Zn(II) unit. The coordination geometry around each Zn(II) is a distorted trigonal bipyramid, which is completed by two N atoms (N1, N5B, from 3,4′-bpt, Zn–N = 2.026(2)–2.045(2) Å) and one O atom (O3A, from suc ligand, Zn–O = 2.031(2) Å) as the trigonal plane, and two O atoms (O2A, O4, from suc ligand, Zn–O = 1.9709(18)–2.296(2) Å) as the apexes. As depicted in Figure a, one of the suc carboxylate groups adopts a chelating mode, but the others have a monodentate coordination fashion to connect the adjacent Zn(II) cations, forming a 1-D chain. The further link by 3,4′-Hbpt ligands bridging the Zn(II)-suc chains with 21 helicity along the b direction, in which the helical pitch is equal to the length of the b axis, made it have an interesting 1-D double chain arrangement, as shown in Figure b and c. The distances between the Zn(II) centers separated by 3,4′-bpt and suc are 11.396(2) Å and 7.166(1) Å, respectively.

[Zn(suc)0.5(3,4'-bpt)(H2O)] (6)

Compound 6 reveals a 1-D system with a mononuclear Zn(II) unit. The coordination geometry around each Zn(II) is a distorted trigonal bipyramid, which is completed by two N atoms (N1, N5B, from 3,4'-bpt, Zn-N = 2.026(2)-2.045(2) Å) and one O atom (O3A, from suc ligand, Zn-O = 2.031(2) Å) as the trigonal plane, and two O atoms (O2A, O4, from suc ligand, Zn-O = 1.9709(18)-2.296(2) Å) as the apexes. As depicted in Figure a, one of the suc carboxylate groups adopts a chelating mode, but the others have a monodentate coordination fashion to connect the adjacent Zn(II) cations, forming a 1-D chain. The further link by 3,4'-Hbpt ligands bridging the Zn(II)-suc chains with 21 helicity along the b direction, in which the helical pitch is equal to the length of the b axis, made it have an interesting 1-D double chain arrangement, as shown in Figure b and c. The distances between the Zn(II) centers separated by 3,4'-bpt and suc are 11.396(2) Å and 7.166(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Local coordination environments of the Zn(II) atoms (a), the 1-D layer of 6 formed by the [Zn(suc)] n chain and the 3,4′-bpt connector (b), and the left- and right-handed helical chains of [Zn(3,4′-bpt)] n (c).
elements.clean_text: 6  Local coordination environments of the Zn(II) atoms (a), the 1-D layer of 6 formed by the [Zn(suc)] n  chain and the 3,4'-bpt connector (b), and the left- and right-handed helical chains of [Zn(3,4'-bpt)] n  (c).

elements.content: Compound 7 consists of a centrosymmetrical binuclear Zn(II) unit. Each Zn(II) has a tetrahedrally coordination mode, which constitutes two carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O3, Zn–O = 1.975(2)–1.985(2) Å) and two N atoms (N4, N1A, from 3,3′-Hbpt ligand, Zn–N = 1.971(2)–2.039(2) Å). As shown in Figure , a pair of 3,3′-bpt molecules act as the bidentate bridge to link Zn(II) atoms by both pyridyl N atoms and 1,2,4-triazole N atoms, which afford a bimetallic ring motif with an intramolecular Zn···Zn distance of 7.617(1) Å. Both of the carboxylic groups in the suc ligands adopt monodentate coordination fashions to bridge two binuclear units, furnishing a 1-D chain. It should be note that, compared with compounds 1–6, the coordination modes of the 3,3′-bpt ligands in 7 become more diversity, where both the pyridyl N atoms and the 1,2,4-triazole N atoms act as a potential monodentate sites. The uncoordinated 1,2,4-triazole N atoms of 3,3′-bpt ligands are hydrogen bonded by coordinated water molecules and neighboring coordinated carboxylate O atoms to furnish a 3D architecture (Figure S3 in the ).
elements.clean_text:
[Zn(suc)0.5(3,3'-bpt)(H2O)] (7)

Compound 7 consists of a centrosymmetrical binuclear Zn(II) unit. Each Zn(II) has a tetrahedrally coordination mode, which constitutes two carboxylate/water O atoms (O1, O3, Zn-O = 1.975(2)-1.985(2) Å) and two N atoms (N4, N1A, from 3,3'-Hbpt ligand, Zn-N = 1.971(2)-2.039(2) Å). As shown in Figure , a pair of 3,3'-bpt molecules act as the bidentate bridge to link Zn(II) atoms by both pyridyl N atoms and 1,2,4-triazole N atoms, which afford a bimetallic ring motif with an intramolecular Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 7.617(1) Å. Both of the carboxylic groups in the suc ligands adopt monodentate coordination fashions to bridge two binuclear units, furnishing a 1-D chain. It should be note that, compared with compounds 1-6, the coordination modes of the 3,3'-bpt ligands in 7 become more diversity, where both the pyridyl N atoms and the 1,2,4-triazole N atoms act as a potential monodentate sites. The uncoordinated 1,2,4-triazole N atoms of 3,3'-bpt ligands are hydrogen bonded by coordinated water molecules and neighboring coordinated carboxylate O atoms to furnish a 3D architecture (Figure S3 in the ).

elements.content: It should be note that a variety of framework structures can be achieved on the basis of the choice of the aliphatic dicarboxylate and triazole-containing dipyridyl isomers with differently oriented pyridyl groups as building blocks, where 1–3 form similar 2D layer structures and 4–7 form different 1D chains. The phenomenon of structural diversification in 1–7 may arise from three different sources: (i) The aliphatic linkers with two separated carboxylate groups can adopt the unidentate, chelating, and bridging modes, respectively. (ii) The differently oriented pyridyl N atoms in these triazole-containing isomers, which have a bent backbone, may play significant roles in the formation of different structures. Moreover, the N atoms of the triazole ring can provide potential coordination or hydrogen bonding sites that will influence the final coordination architectures (). (iii) The coordinated geometries of different metal centers may benefit the structural diversification of the resultant extended networks. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, it can generally be discovered that, in all these structures we have obtained from our previous works, the dicarboxylate ligands link the metal centers to form 1D chains or 2D layers, and their final structural diversities mainly come from the further extension of the arrays by the isomeric bpt connectors in different directions, which however cannot be accurately forecasted.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity of 1-7 

It should be note that a variety of framework structures can be achieved on the basis of the choice of the aliphatic dicarboxylate and triazole-containing dipyridyl isomers with differently oriented pyridyl groups as building blocks, where 1-3 form similar 2D layer structures and 4-7 form different 1D chains. The phenomenon of structural diversification in 1-7 may arise from three different sources: (i) The aliphatic linkers with two separated carboxylate groups can adopt the unidentate, chelating, and bridging modes, respectively. (ii) The differently oriented pyridyl N atoms in these triazole-containing isomers, which have a bent backbone, may play significant roles in the formation of different structures. Moreover, the N atoms of the triazole ring can provide potential coordination or hydrogen bonding sites that will influence the final coordination architectures (). (iii) The coordinated geometries of different metal centers may benefit the structural diversification of the resultant extended networks. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, it can generally be discovered that, in all these structures we have obtained from our previous works, the dicarboxylate ligands link the metal centers to form 1D chains or 2D layers, and their final structural diversities mainly come from the further extension of the arrays by the isomeric bpt connectors in different directions, which however cannot be accurately forecasted.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1–3 and 5 were carried out on crushed single crystals in the 2.0–300.0 K range at 1000 Oe. The magnetic behaviors of 1 are shown as χM T vs T plots in Figure . The χM T value of 6.55 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K is much higher than the theoretical spin-only value (3.76 cm3 K mol–1) of two noninteracting Co(II) ions. The higher value is presumably due to the orbital contribution, which is common for high-spin octahedral Co(II) complexes. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases continuously, reaching a minimum of 4.09 cm3 K mol–1 at 12 K, and then, the χM T product experiences an upturn, increasing quickly to a value of 4.96 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. This behavior can be qualitatively explained as due to the fact that high-spin octahedral Co(II) has an orbital degenerate ground state 4T1. The decrease in χM T down to 12 K basically corresponds to a single-ion behavior, which accounts for the splitting of the 4T1 term into six Kramers doublets as a consequence of the combined effect of spin–orbit coupling and distortion from ideal octahedral symmetry. Then, the observed increase in χM T below this temperature is no longer coming from the single-ion behavior but rather from the presence of intramolecular weak ferromagnetism, which may be caused by small uncompensated AF spin-canting behavior between the Co(II) ions. Compound 2 has similar structural and magnetic properties with those of 1, as shown in Figure . The value of χM T is 6.46 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases continuously, reaching a minimum of 4.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 12 K, accounting for single-ion behavior of the Co(II) ions. And then, the χM T product experiences an upturn, increasing quickly to a value of 3.04 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K.

elements.content: Spin canting, i.e., perfect antiparallel alignment of the spins on the neighboring metal ions, is not achieved so that residual spins are generated. Usually, the canting effect is caused by antisymmetric interactions linked to the symmetry of the exchange pathways joining the magnetic centers and also to single ion anisotropy. The canting in 1 and 2 may be caused by (1) the strong magnetic anisotropy of the Co(II) ions, where the local anisotropy is due to first-order spin–orbit coupling, and (2) the acentrosymmetric syn–anti carboxylato bridge of the chains, thus satisfying the requirement for the Dzyaloshinski–Moriya interaction. In addition, the bent ligands (4,4′-abpt and 4,4′-Hbpt), tilting the neighbor octahedral Co(II) centers, could also give a further contribution.

In addition, the bent ligands (4,4'-abpt and 4,4'-Hbpt), tilting the neighbor octahedral Co(II) centers, could also give a further contribution.

elements.content: For 3, the magnetic behavior is plotted as χM T versus T in Figure a. The value of χM T at room temperature is 2.15 cm3 K mol–1, a little larger than that expected for the spin-only value (2.00 cm3 K mol–1) of two magnetically isolated Ni(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T product decreases slowly until a minimum (2.08 cm3 K mol–1) at 75 K, indicating a dominant weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the Ni(II) ions, and then increases quickly to a maximum (2.71 cm3 K mol–1) at 3 K, indicating a system of spin canting followed by the existence of single-ion magnetic anisotropy (D parameter) together with the presence of an antisymmetric exchange between the Ni(II) ions, and finally slightly decreases, which may be caused by some impurity.

elements.content: The 1/χM vs T plot (300–30 K) is exactly linear following the Curie–Weiss law, with Curie constant C = 2.15 cm3 K mol–1 and Weiss constant θ = −1.86 K. The isothermal magnetization at 2.0 K (Figure b, inset) shows a paramagnetic behavior without long-range magnetic ordering, with a featureless increase with the field until reaching the saturation moment. The zero-field ac magnetic susceptibility measurement (Figure b) shows no in-phase signal before 2 K.

elements.content: For 5, the form of χM T versus T is shown in Figure . The data above 30 K obey the Curie–Weiss law, with C = 3.49 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −33.203 K. At room temperature, the value of χM T is 3.14 cm3 K mol–1, much larger than that expected for the spin-only value (1.88 cm3 K mol–1) of magnetically isolated Co(II) ions, indicating the important contribution of spin–orbit coupling. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually, reaching a minimum of 1.76 cm3 K mol–1 at 4 K, accounting for the single-ion behavior of Co(II) ion. Below 4 K, the χM T curve shows a sharp rise to get a value of 1.91 cm3 K mol–1. This behavior may indicate the occurrence of a weak ferromagnetic interaction. In 5, the nearest Co···Co separation through the interlayer H-bonds is 7.342 Å; the long distances suggest a very weak efficient direct exchange between the Co(II) ions. From the structural view, 3,4′-Hbpt has no inversion center and may be used as a asymmetric bridge to tilt the coordination geometry of adjacent Co(II) centers, thus resulting in the generation of spin canting.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TG) were carried out for complexes 1–3 and 5–7, and the results are shown in Figure . The TGA curves of 1, 2, and 5 are similar, suggesting that the first weight loss of 11.08% for 1 (11.14% for 2 and 15.83% for 5) in the region 193–261 °C (173–251 °C for 2 and 159–223 °C for 5) corresponds to the release of the lattice water and coordinated water (calculated 11.56% for 1, 11.94% for 2, and 15.31% for 5), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C (700 °C for 2 and 714 °C for 5). For 3, the first weight loss of 8.51% in the region of 141–175 °C corresponds to the release of the lattice water (calculated 7.96%), the second step of weight loss of 3.66% in the region of 211–352 °C corresponds to the release of the coordinated water (calculated 3.98%), the third step of weight loss of 46.88% in the region of 412 °C corresponds to the release of the Hbpt ligands (calculated 47.57%), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C. For 6, the complex is stable up to 340 °C, followed by a series of consecutive steps of weight loss that do not stop until heating ends. For 7, a series of consecutive steps of weight loss does not stop until heating ends.

Thermal Stabilities of the Complexes

Thermogravimetric analyses (TG) were carried out for complexes 1-3 and 5-7, and the results are shown in Figure . The TGA curves of 1, 2, and 5 are similar, suggesting that the first weight loss of 11.08% for 1 (11.14% for 2 and 15.83% for 5) in the region 193-261 °C (173-251 °C for 2 and 159-223 °C for 5) corresponds to the release of the lattice water and coordinated water (calculated 11.56% for 1, 11.94% for 2, and 15.31% for 5), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C (700 °C for 2 and 714 °C for 5). For 3, the first weight loss of 8.51% in the region of 141-175 °C corresponds to the release of the lattice water (calculated 7.96%), the second step of weight loss of 3.66% in the region of 211-352 °C corresponds to the release of the coordinated water (calculated 3.98%), the third step of weight loss of 46.88% in the region of 412 °C corresponds to the release of the Hbpt ligands (calculated 47.57%), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C. For 6, the complex is stable up to 340 °C, followed by a series of consecutive steps of weight loss that do not stop until heating ends. For 7, a series of consecutive steps of weight loss does not stop until heating ends.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds have been attracting more interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. In this paper, the photoluminescence spectra of compounds 4, 6, and 7 in the solid state were studied at room temperature, and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure . The emission spectra have broad peaks with maxima at 420 nm (λex = 366 nm), 398 nm (λex = 308 nm), and 369 nm (λex = 326 nm) for 4, 6, and 7, respectively, whereas the emission peaks for the free ligands 4,4′-Hbpt, 3,4′-Hbpt, and 3,3′-Hbpt were observed at 447 nm, 451 nm, and 488 nm (λex = 368 nm, 378 nm, and 419 nm, respectively). The blue shifts of the luminescence emission maxima in 4, 6, and 7 are presumably owing to the result of the coordination of the relevant ligands to a metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and asymmetry of the ligands. The luminescence intensity of 4 is intensely increasing, possibly as a result of the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

Luminescent compounds have been attracting more interest because of their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. In this paper, the photoluminescence spectra of compounds 4, 6, and 7 in the solid state were studied at room temperature, and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure . The emission spectra have broad peaks with maxima at 420 nm (λex = 366 nm), 398 nm (λex = 308 nm), and 369 nm (λex = 326 nm) for 4, 6, and 7, respectively, whereas the emission peaks for the free ligands 4,4'-Hbpt, 3,4'-Hbpt, and 3,3'-Hbpt were observed at 447 nm, 451 nm, and 488 nm (λex = 368 nm, 378 nm, and 419 nm, respectively). The blue shifts of the luminescence emission maxima in 4, 6, and 7 are presumably owing to the result of the coordination of the relevant ligands to a metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and asymmetry of the ligands. The luminescence intensity of 4 is intensely increasing, possibly as a result of the metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT).

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized seven coordination polymers under solvothermal conditions using a series of structurally related bent ligands and succinic acid. 1–3 have a 2D layer coordination structure exhibiting weak ferromagnetic behaviors caused by spin-canting, and 5 has a 1D arrangement with a mononuclear Co(II) unit, also showing the phenomenon of spin canting. The contribution of bent ligands to the canting effect through tilting the neighbor metal centers has been mentioned. Photoluminescence studies revealed, compared with the bpt ligands, that the luminescence emission maxima of 4, 6, and 7 show blue shifts in different levers and that the fluorescence intensity of 4 is intensely increasing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized seven coordination polymers under solvothermal conditions using a series of structurally related bent ligands and succinic acid. 1-3 have a 2D layer coordination structure exhibiting weak ferromagnetic behaviors caused by spin-canting, and 5 has a 1D arrangement with a mononuclear Co(II) unit, also showing the phenomenon of spin canting. The contribution of bent ligands to the canting effect through tilting the neighbor metal centers has been mentioned. Photoluminescence studies revealed, compared with the bpt ligands, that the luminescence emission maxima of 4, 6, and 7 show blue shifts in different levers and that the fluorescence intensity of 4 is intensely increasing.

Anal. Calcd for C28H26CdN10O6: C, 47.26; H, 3.66; N, 19.69. Found: C, 46.44; H, 3.98; N, 19.16. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3089m, 1614m, 1550s, 1383m, 1145w, 993w, 845w, 726 m, 650w.

Synthesis of [Co(suc)(3,4'-Hbpt)(H2O)3]⋅H2O (5)

 5 was synthesized similarly to compound 1 except using 3,4'-Hbpt instead of 4,4'-abpt, giving red block crystalline products in a 50% yield (base on Co(II)). Anal. Calcd for C16H19CoN5O8: C, 40.82; H, 4.04; N, 14.88. Found: C, 40.40; H, 4.66; N, 14.35. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3342s, 1624m, 1567s, 1416s, 1292m, 1157w, 973m, 847w, 732m, 601w.

Synthesis of [Zn(suc)(3,4'-Hbpt)(H2O)] (6)

 6 was synthesized similarly to compound 1 except using Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 3,4'-Hbpt instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 4,4'-abpt, respectively, giving colorless block crystalline products in a 52% yield (base on Zn(II)). Anal. Calcd for C16H13ZnN5O4: C, 47.44; H, 3.21; N, 17.30. Found: C, 47.52; H, 3.45; N, 17.42. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3076w, 1626s, 1583s, 1547s, 1409s, 1293m, 1185w, 1026w, 981m, 890m, 698w, 553w.

Synthesis of [Zn(suc)0.5(3,3'-bpt)(H2O)] (7)

 7 was synthesized similarly to compound 1 except using Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 3,3'-Hbpt instead of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 4,4'-abpt, respectively, giving colorless block crystalline products in a 48% yield (base on Zn(II)). cln_elements.content:
Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1–3 and 5 were carried out on crushed single crystals in the 2.0–300.0 K range at 1000 Oe. The magnetic behaviors of 1 are shown as χM T vs T plots in Figure . The χM T value of 6.55 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K is much higher than the theoretical spin-only value (3.76 cm3 K mol–1) of two noninteracting Co(II) ions. The higher value is presumably due to the orbital contribution, which is common for high-spin octahedral Co(II) complexes. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases continuously, reaching a minimum of 4.09 cm3 K mol–1 at 12 K, and then, the χM T product experiences an upturn, increasing quickly to a value of 4.96 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. This behavior can be qualitatively explained as due to the fact that high-spin octahedral Co(II) has an orbital degenerate ground state 4T1. The decrease in χM T down to 12 K basically corresponds to a single-ion behavior, which accounts for the splitting of the 4T1 term into six Kramers doublets as a consequence of the combined effect of spin–orbit coupling and distortion from ideal octahedral symmetry. Then, the observed increase in χM T below this temperature is no longer coming from the single-ion behavior but rather from the presence of intramolecular weak ferromagnetism, which may be caused by small uncompensated AF spin-canting behavior between the Co(II) ions. Compound 2 has similar structural and magnetic properties with those of 1, as shown in Figure . The value of χM T is 6.46 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases continuously, reaching a minimum of 4.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 12 K, accounting for single-ion behavior of the Co(II) ions. And then, the χM T product experiences an upturn, increasing quickly to a value of 3.04 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K.

Thermal Stabilities of the Complexes

Thermogravimetric analyses (TG) were carried out for complexes 1–3 and 5–7, and the results are shown in Figure . The TGA curves of 1, 2, and 5 are similar, suggesting that the first weight loss of 11.08% for 1 (11.14% for 2 and 15.83% for 5) in the region 193–261 °C (173–251 °C for 2 and 159–223 °C for 5) corresponds to the release of the lattice water and coordinated water (calculated 11.56% for 1, 11.94% for 2, and 15.31% for 5), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C (700 °C for 2 and 714 °C for 5). For 3, the first weight loss of 8.51% in the region of 141–175 °C corresponds to the release of the lattice water (calculated 7.96%), the second step of weight loss of 3.66% in the region of 211–352 °C corresponds to the release of the coordinated water (calculated 3.98%), the third step of weight loss of 46.88% in the region of 412 °C corresponds to the release of the Hbpt ligands (calculated 47.57%), and then, a series of complicated weight losses were observed as the temperature increased until heating ends at 700 °C. For 6, the complex is stable up to 340 °C, followed by a series of consecutive steps of weight loss that do not stop until heating ends. For 7, a series of consecutive steps of weight loss does not stop until heating ends.

Then, the observed increase in χM T below this temperature is no longer coming from the single-ion behavior but rather from the presence of intramolecular weak ferromagnetism, which may be caused by small uncompensated AF spin-canting behavior between the Co(II) ions.
